author: Elliot Hannon
title: Trump reportedly picks Jon Huntsman as Russia ambassador.
text:
March 8 2017 11:08 PM Trump Reportedly Picks Former Utah Gov. Jon Huntsman as Ambassador to Russia Jon Huntsman at the Council on Foreign Relations January 29, 2015 in Washington, DC. Alex Wong/Getty Images 
President Trump tapped former Utah Gov. Jon Huntsman to be his man in Moscow and the 2012 presidential candidate has accepted the position, administration officials said Tuesday. Huntsman, who last served as Obama‚Äôs ambassador to China, will assume the ambassadorship, heading the American diplomatic mission that will be charged with navigating the treacherous domestic terrain that is the Trump administration‚Äôs relationship with the Kremlin. 
If confirmed, Huntsman will come to the job as an outsider in the Trump universe. Huntsman has served under both Democratic and Republican administrations. Moderate and measured, Huntsman, in many ways, is the anti-Trump in style and substance. The former ambassador also sparred with his new boss during the 2016 campaign. From the Washington Post : The former governor, a Mormon, had an up-and-down relationship with Trump during last year‚Äôs campaign. He was slow to endorse any candidate for the Republican nomination though did back Trump once he became the presumptive nominee. But Huntsman then called for Trump to drop out after the October release of a 2005 video in which Trump is captured on a hot microphone making lewd comments about women. He said then that the ‚Äúcampaign cycle has been nothing but a race to the bottom‚Äù and called for Trump‚Äôs running mate, then-Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, to top the GOP ticket. 
Trump has also had a few, ahem, nasty things to say about Huntsman: Just a few of the nice things Trump has said in the past about Jon Huntsman, his new Ambassador to Russia. üíï pic.twitter.com/YoJSSFms2K ‚Äî shauna (@goldengateblond) March 9, 2017 
Besides Secretary of State Tillerson, Huntsman will be perhaps the highest profile member of Trump‚Äôs diplomatic corps that has largely been sidelined early in his presidency. The Moscow posting is a perilous one in this administration. At this point, for Huntsman, it's unclear what success would look like, as closer ties with the Kremlin will smack of nefarious double-dealing by a White House that has had seeminly endless questionable ties to the country. Not to mention, acting as a go-between between Trump and Moscow has already torpedoed many in the Trump camp‚Äîand that's before the myriad of Russia investigations have really taken off and subpoenas have been handed out.
